entry.title: [Office upload] Handle sign in click in reauthentication required state
entry.content:
Handle sign in link click in ODFS reauthentication required (empty)

state. This state is shown when ODFS threw an ACCESS_DENIED error upon

onReadDirectoryRequested. The sign in link handler requests a new ODFS

mount upon clicking. ODFS will unmount the old mount if the

authentication is successful in the new mount.



Also remove the settings link and update the text to match UX specs.



Screen: https://screenshot.googleplex.com/4WLgi37rDuwhcZF.png

entry.title: [A11y] Enhance performance by targeting value updates to specific nodes
entry.content:
This is a performance improvement mostly for ProcessDeferredAccessibilityEvents(), although it does seem to improve SendPendingAccessibilityEvents() and in some cases unserialization in BrowserAccessibilityManager::OnAccessibilityEvents() as well. Also fixes some crashes in referenced issues.



Previously, when a change occurs to the DOM or layout tree, accessibility increments AXObjectCacheImpl::modification_count_, which has the effect of invalidating the cached values on all AXObjects in the tree. The next time one of those properties is fetched, AXObject::UpdateCachedAttributeValuesIfNeeded() will recompute all of the cached values for that AXObject. (However, since these objects are not marked dirty, no additional reserialization happened other than the actually necessary nodes, and the overhead was just in Blink.)



However, for most changes, it is only necessary to update the cached values for the AXObject that has changed, or potentially for a subtree. This CL implements that by providing 3 methods:

* AXObject::InvalidateCachedValues() for invalidating a single AXObject

* InvalidateCachedValuesOnSubtreeWithFlatTraversal(Node*), which is useful for visibility:hidden and aria-hidden toggles

* InvalidateCachedValuesOnAllObjects() for invalidating all AXObjects in the tree.



Explanation of test changes:

* content-visibility tests: redundant whitespace nodes are now removed once a subtree gains layout, so that the AXObject subtree looks identical whether the layout was provided from the beginning or gained later

* visibility:hidden tests: added more content because we lacked test coverage of deep subtree invalidations.

* Linux event tests: redundant events are now removed

* other-aria-attribute-change-sends-notification.html: AriaAttributeChanged is no longer needed

* is-ignored-change-sends-notification.html: improvement as redundant notification is no longer fired, because the visibility hidden child does not change it's tree inclusion status (visibility hidden objects are currently ignored but included in the tree).



Follow-ups:

* Try to remove Event::kAriaAttributeChanged everywhere, it is not necessary (CL:4500419)

* Look into queuing up fewer callbacks for attribute changes (CL:4500424)

* Remove loop inside ProcessDeferredAccessibilityEvents() and other code used to handle content-visibility:auto locked state changes, now that we just remove subtrees and recompute them all predictably (CL:4528195).

* Try to remove lifecycle switch in Remove(Document*)

* Unify code that invalidates/recomputes the cached_can_set_focus_ member with our other cached attribute invalidations (CL:4528735)

* Simplify code to force clean layout in AXNodeObject::OnNativeFocusAction() (CL:4532955)

* Get rid of modification_count_ and instead rely on a boolean that indicates the cache values are invalidated. See TODO in AXObjectCacheImpl::MarkDocumentDirty() (CL:4528696).



Fixed: 1434555, 1362758

Cq-Do-Not-Cancel-Tryjobs: true

Change-Id: Iecb56b877392954e7ce1fea37a9472b68ba5364f

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4466969

Reviewed-by: Chris Harrelson

Commit-Queue: Aaron Leventhal

entry.title: Crash Report - media_router::MirroringActivity::OnSessionSet
entry.content:
Probably the reason causing the issue is that `host_` is null and we are trying to get a weak_ptr to it.

We already have `DCHECK(host_)`, but since in production builds DCHECKs are ignored, I replaced it with if statement.





Not sure what might have caused this issue. It might be because `host_` definition happens on the ui thread, but it is also used on io thread. So, there might be a case where ui thread is somehow slow/blocked and io is working fine.

entry.title: Add location.reload() document state test
entry.content:
This CL is a follow-up to https://crrev.com/c/3936785 and

https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/6813#issuecomment-1273124537. It

adds a test asserting the document state preservation as described more

below, in the `location.reload()` case, alongside a very similar test

that asserts the same for the document repopulation case.



The HTML Standard specifies the behavior of `location.reload()` to

preserve the existing history entry's document state's initiator origin

and referrer, as described in:

https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/browsing-the-web.html#apply-the-history-step:~:text=If%20targetEntry%27s%20document%20is%20null%2C%20or%20targetEntry%27s%20document%20state%27s%20reload%20pending%20is%20true%2C%20then.



This means that when a page is navigated to from a cross-origin

predecessor, and then `location.reload()`s itself, `Sec-Fetch-Site`

should be `cross-site` and the `Referer` header should remain the same

as the original navigation.



Chromium currently fails this test, per

https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/6813#issuecomment-894460102 and

the code pointer described by that comment.



R=domenic@chromium.org



Bug: N/A

entry.title: ARC: Support 'one time' state for permissions
entry.content:
ARC permissions can be in a one-time granted state, which means the user

will be asked again about whether to allow the permission on next use.

This CL adds support for this value, and changes all ARC permissions to

report to App Service as TriState values. Using TriState values is

mostly an invisible change, since most places just convert the value to

a boolean anyway, but there is one spot in notification handling which

needs correcting.



ARC change: ag/23241038

entry.title: [Extensions] Allow sidePanel.open() to open inactive contextual panels
entry.content:
If sidePanel.open() is supplied the tab ID of an inactive tab, it should

open the side panel in that tab. In the case of a contextual panel, this

should *only* open in the inactive tab (i.e., not open in the current

tab).



Add support for this, along with browsertests for the same.

entry.title: Detect redirect loops in HttpsUpgradesInterceptor
entry.content:
HttpsUpgradesInterceptor will now track the URLs it has seen, and when

handling a navigation request that is for a URL that it has already seen

it will instead trigger fallback to avoid the redirect loop. Previously,

redirect loops could be handled by the underlying max redirects in the

network stack, but this behavior could be slow or flakey. Detecting

loops directly in the Interceptor should be more robust, and can be

done sooner than the max redirects error.



This also fixes a difference in how hostnames were added to the

HTTPS-First Mode allowlist versus the HTTPS-Upgrades allowlist.

Previously, HTTPS-First Mode added the fallback URL hostname to the

allowlist after interstitial click through, but HTTPS-Upgrades added

the failed request URL (potentially different from the fallback URL) to

the allowlist when handling the failure before triggering fallback.

After this change, HTTPS-Upgrades now adds the fallback URL to the

allowlist regardless of the current request URL, which aligns with the

pre-existing HTTPS-First Mode behavior.



Bug: 1394910,1432435

entry.title: [SuperSize] Caspian: Fix null dereference and remove mysterious "emsc" path.
entry.content:
Previously SuperSize Viewer shows inconsistent paths for aggregate

padding diff symbols for dense vs. sparse diffs: Dense diffs show these

under path "emsc", whereas sparse diffs show these under "(No path)".

This was mysterious since the string "emsc" was absent from source and

.size / .sizediff files.



It turns out that "emsc" came from dereferencing nullptr, which was

benign since address 0 stores bytes 65 6D 73 63 00 00 ...! The null

dereference occurs because Symbol::GroupingPath() has missing null

checks.



This CL provides the proper null check to Symbol::GroupingPath(). As a

result, aggregate padding diff symbols for dense diffs now appears in

"(No path)", like sparse diffs.



Bug: 1047572

entry.title: WebView: Changing how we delay initial Fast Mode seed fetch.
entry.content:
WebView initially delayed Fast Mode seed fetches using PostTask#postDelayedTask. However, this is not a valid way to do so because this relies on the native library being loaded. The native library is not loaded in nonembedded WebView. This change uses the JobeService's persistable bundle to track whether enough time has passed for the initial delay period.



Bug: 1395513

entry.title: gpu: Fix graphite dawn texture usage mismatches
entry.content:
Non-root render passes need the CopySrc texture usage - add that and

CopyDst to GetGraphiteTextureInfo. Add an additional parameter to make

sure those are not added for the root surface where it's not always

supported e.g. with Dawn swap chains.



Make SkiaOutputDeviceDawn check that the supported surface texture usage

is at least RenderAttachment and TextureBinding, and adjust the calls

to GetGraphiteTextureInfo there and in BeginPaintCurrentFrame to set

`root_surface` = true.



Also add logging handlers in DawnContextProvider which makes it possible

to see validation errors in dcheck builds.



Bug: 1434131

entry.title: Set IME consumed flag for the event synthesized by InputMethodAsh.
entry.content:
The key event is not marked as consumed, thus, exo occasionally

misunderstands whether the key event is consumed or not.



Specifically, the flag needs to be consistent between

exo::Keyboard::OnKey and exo::TextInput::InsertChar, so propagate

the same flag.

entry.title: OOP-VD: Kill utility process when all decoders in it die.
entry.content:
A renderer process can create a media::mojom::VideoDecoder during start

up in order to query the supported video decode acceleration

configurations. With OOP-VD, this causes the creation of a utility video

decoder process. Before this CL, this process would stay alive even

after the renderer process tore down the connection to it. That means

that there would always be one utility video decoder process per

renderer process that behaves as above. In practice, this has dire

memory pressure consequences since each utility process consumes some

memory even if it isn't doing any work.



The reason the video decoder process stays alive is that the only thing

that happens in this process when a StableVideoDecoder is disconnected

is that a mojo::Receiver is removed from a

mojo::UniqueReceiverSet. As long as the StableVideoDecoderFactory and

StableVideoDecoderFactoryProcess connections stay alive, the process

stays alive. The StableVideoDecoderFactory is maintained by the browser

for each RenderProcessHostImpl. The browser process doesn't know when

all the StableVideoDecoder connections have ended, so it doesn't know

when to destroy the StableVideoDecoderFactory connection.



This CL adds code that destroys the StableVideoDecoderFactory connection

once all the StableVideoDecoders created with it have died. The approach

is to add a StableVideoDecoderTracker interface with no methods. The

browser process sends a mojo::PendingRemote

at the moment of calling

StableVideoDecoderFactory::CreateStableVideoDecoder(). When the created

StableVideoDecoder dies, the StableVideoDecoderTracker connection also

dies. The browser process can handle this disconnection and destroy the

StableVideoDecoderFactory when all StableVideoDecoderTracker connections

die.



>>> Q&As about this approach:



- Why not just handle a disconnection of the

mojo::Remote?



The browser does not own a mojo::Remote. The

browser only acts as a broker to establish a StableVideoDecoder

connection, but it sends the mojo::PendingRemote

to the GPU process where it's bound to a

mojo::Remote. The GPU process can't control the

state of the StableVideoDecoderFactory connection, so we can't use a

StableVideoDecoder disconnection event in that process for our needs.



- Ok, so why not handle a disconnection of the

mojo::Receiver then?



This was actually my initial approach. We already have code that

handles the disconnection of the

mojo::Receiver in the utility process [1];

when that happens, we disconnect the

mojo::Receiver [2] which should

cause the utility process to die. This handles things like a renderer

process dying. I had extended this to also handle a disconnection of

each mojo::Receiver: when there were no more

connected mojo::Receivers we could destroy the

StableVideoDecoderFactoryProcess connection. This was mostly fine but

there was a timing problem. To illustrate, consider the following

sequence of events under this hypothetical implementation:



1) A renderer process requests one mojo connection to do hardware

video decoding. Suppose this is the only video decoding connection

(e.g., there's only one video playing).



2) To satisfy this, the browser process starts a video decoder utility

process to host a StableVideoDecoderFactory. It establishes a

StableVideoDecoder connection using the

mojo::Remote.



3) The renderer process terminates its connection.



4) The termination of the first connection causes the

StableVideoDecoder connection to die. Because it's the only one so

far, the video decoder process gets destroyed.



5) The renderer process starts a new connection. (3) and (5) may

happen if the renderer process wants to start playing another

video.



6) Suppose the browser process hasn't gotten notified of the video

decoder process termination from (4). That means that it thinks the

mojo::Remote from (2) is still connected

so it re-uses it to establish the StableVideoDecoder connection we

need for (5).



In reality, since the StableVideoDecoderFactory connection from (2)

has already died, the "established" StableVideoDecoder connection in

(6) is bogus, so it can't be used for video decoding. Ultimately, this

will cause the renderer to fallback to software decoding.



Therefore, it's not good enough to monitor the

mojo::Receiver as the race condition described

above may become problematic in practice.



With the solution implemented in this CL, we don't need to worry about

this scenario since the browser process will know exactly when the

StableVideoDecoderFactory connection dies due to all the

StableVideoDecoders having died.



>>> Versioning considerations:



It proved difficult to make this CL work smoothly with an older version

of the StableVideoDecoderFactory interface. However, that's not much of

a problem in practice. The only scenario where version skew can occur is

with LaCrOS. OOP-VD for LaCrOS was enabled by default starting in M114,

but I have landed CL:4532897 that disables it back in M114. OOP-VD for

LaCrOS is still enabled by default on ToT. Therefore, in practice, end

users should always use OOP-VD with the changes introduced in this CL

(both for the client and the service). That's unless they run a weird

setup of, e.g., a newer lacros-chrome canary/dev with an older

ash-chrome canary/dev. Instead of trying to handle this version skew

which would have added more complexity for little benefit, I've added a

RequireVersion() in this CL. Here are the worst-case scenarios with

OOP-VD enabled (which is the case for LaCrOS on ToT):



- lacros-chrome with this CL + ash-chrome without this CL:



The StableVideoDecoderFactory connection should die almost immediately

due to the RequireVersion(). This should cause all hardware video

decode requests to fallback to software.



As M115 progresses, this should become a very rare scenario.



- lacros-chrome without this CL + ash-chrome with this CL:



The StableVideoDecoderTracker connection is optional. In this

scenario, ash-chrome should receive a null

mojo::PendingRemote which is fine, but

things will just behave as before this CL: hardware video decoding can

still be done, but the "leak" of video decoder processes will be

there.



As M115 progresses, this should also become a very rare scenario.



[1] https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:media/mojo/services/stable_video_decoder_factory_service.cc;l=182;drc=dfc607e946e8862d54aa06d7c63e5b617e88f56f

[2] https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:media/mojo/services/stable_video_decoder_factory_process_service.cc;l=48-50;drc=a1abb372f2784fb1264e8fc4815255f410e1a2be



Bug: 1444970, b:195769334

Test: on brya, crosvideo.appspot.com on lacros-chrome while monitoring the task manager

Test: unit tests

Change-Id: I07ce73348fafd209802c82884550804478f2dfa9

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4538864

Reviewed-by: Dale Curtis

Reviewed-by: Alex Moshchuk

Reviewed-by: Alex Gough

Reviewed-by: Pilar Molina Lopez

entry.content:

Chromium with Dawn since we instantiate a new WGPUTexture on each scoped

access so we want to use volatile promise images instead.

entry.title: Launch crash-uploader from linux host script
entry.content:
This CL adds logic to the CRD host script to launch the crash-uploader

binary alongside the host binary. It is hooked into the relaunch logic

so if the uploader process crashes or is killed, it will be relaunched.

One other note is that while the host will end up going offline if the

crash-uploader goes into a crash-loop itself, a single process exit

will not affect the current session.



Also, I am only enabling this logic for Googlers in this CL. Since we

have access to the host config in the script, I decided to key off of

the host_owner field here, there are other approaches I could have

taken but this seemed like the simplest.



Change-Id: Ief9abec4c467276d06f7bc12cb17372889ac411e

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4528370

Reviewed-by: Lambros Lambrou

entry.title: CrOS Settings: Record metrics for total time settings window is active.
entry.content:
Setting up UMA for sending metrics at the end of a session and recording

the total time that the settings window was active. Active is defined as

Setting app open and in focus. We will be recording the data in a bucket

in histogram named:"ChromeOS.Settings.TotalTimeSettingsWindowIsActive".



go/cros-settings-revamp-metrics-design-doc



Bug= b/280480839

TEST=

Manual:

1. Have a timer available.

2. As soon as you open the Settings app, start the timer. Open another

app and immediately stop the timer. Go back to the Settings app and

resume the timer. Close the Settings app and stop the timer.

3. Open your browser and search "chrome://histograms". search for

“ChromeOS.Settings.TotalTimeSettingsWindowIsActive". there will be one

added to the respective bucket. Note that the bucket will not be the

exact time, but rather a range that the time would fall into.

4. The time that shows up in the histogram is identical to the time that

shows up on your timer.



Automated: run

autoninja -C out/Default unit_tests && DISPLAY=:20 out/Default/unit_tests

--gtest_filter="*PerSessionSettingsUserActionTrackerTest*"

entry.title: Remove speculative RFH fallback from RVHI::GetMainRenderFrameHost
entry.content:
Currently, if RenderViewHostImpl::GetMainRenderFrameHost() doesn't

have an associated main frame RFH, it unexpectedly returns a

*speculative* RFH if one exists. This behavior is weird, because the

speculative RFH may have nothing to do with the RVHI. It was required

in the past by some callers of this function, but it appears that all

of the old dependencies on are now gone. So, remove this fallback

path.

entry.title: Fix regression caused by MultiInstanceManager initialization update
entry.content:
The updates to MultiInstanceManager initialization behavior in

crrev.com/c/4515161 resulted in a regression due to skipping of the

TabModelSelectorTabModelObserver addition when a new Chrome instance is

created, due to the mTabModelSelector Observer#onTabStateInitialized()

implementation in ChromeTabbedActivity#createTabModels() potentially

returning early because mCreatedTabOnStartup is false;

MultiInstanceManager#onTabStateInitialized() should not have a

dependency on this member variable to add the tab model selector

observer and will therefore be invoked before this variable is checked.



This update resolves the following two issues: 1. The activity tab title

stored in the InstanceInfo of a newly created instance is appropriately

updated by the tab model selector observer didSelectTab() method

implementation. 2. The tab count for a newly created instance is

appropriately updated by appropriate tab model selector observer method

implementations.



Bug: 1444638

Change-Id: I89c6db36aa2bb1aaecc06c938136fe9d7ac42a61

entry.title: Introduce OmniboxActionFactory.
entry.content:
This repurposes the ActionChipDelegate and introduces an

OmniboxActionFactory that can directly instantiate OmniboxActions

that can be directly executed.



Previous changes that reshuffled the code made this specific change

possible, but don't fit the modules and components concept very well.



Now that this change is done, we can move implementations entirely

back to //chrome/browser/ui.



There are two things preventing complete consolidation:

1) Tab is not a //component-visible interface. As such, hosting all

the Actions code in //components is not possible.

2) PasswordManagerLauncher and IntentHandler are neither modules nor

components, thus hosting all of the code in the //chrome/browser/ui

is technically not possible either.



Furthermore:

- all plumbing of ActionChipsDelegate is now removed (not needed).

- OmniboxDropdownProcessor gets a new method, `allowOmiboxActions` to

address cases where action in suggest should not be attached, e.g.

HistoryClustersProcessor and ClipboardProcessor both have no

actions.

- OmniboxActionDelegate now reuses OpenHistoryClustersUi functional

interface

- execute() method is now solely hosted by OmniboxAction

implementations.

- OmniboxActionFactory facilitates creation of all OmniboxAction

instances. while technically possible to instantiate them directly,

using factory adds extra coverage.

- omnibox_pedal_jni_wrapper has been repurposed to be an

omnibox_action_factory_android code

- omnibox_pedal_jni_wrapper header and source have both been fixed to

make header pull what it needs, and make source depend on the

header.

entry.title: [OBC] Filter out request cookies based on scheme and port binding
entry.content:
When the appropriate net::features are enabled, cookies will be excluded

from requests if their original setting scheme or port doesn't match

that to of the url's. If the feature(s) are disabled we apply warnings.



Schemes are generally checked to be secure/non-secure with an exception

for potentially trustworthy origins. In these cases we consider the urls

as secure regardless of their actual scheme and allow them access to

cookies with secure source schemes. More details below.



Cookies can also have an "unset" scheme, which means we don't know what

their original setting scheme was (because they already existed before

we started recording it). These cookies are allowed to be sent to any

scheme.



Ports should be an exact match or the cookie should have an unspecified

source port (for similar reasons as an unset scheme). There are similar exceptions for trustworthy urls.



Potentially trustworthy origins (urls):

Trustworthy, but non-cryptographic, urls get access to cookies with both secure and non-secure source schemes. Since secure/non-secure urls generally have different ports, trustworthy urls also get access to

cookies with source ports of both 80 and 443. If the url has a custom

port then we'll only match cookies with that port (and unset ports).



When a cookie with the `Secure` attribute is set on a trustworthy url

we modify its source_scheme to indicate a "secure" source. If the port

is the default value (80) for the url then we'll also modify the

cookie's source_port to 443. This is done to prevent these cookies from becoming inaccessible if the url lost trustworthiness.



This CL also adds the new warning and exclusion reasons.



Bug: 1170548

Change-Id: I6024b294c308f3db64a69df4ec9e2241f7b9e828

entry.title: Re-land: Eagerly update the a11y tree during the lifecycle step.
entry.content:
Difference from original landing:

* Addition of new code from aleventhal to handle unincluded nodes. See

https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4536899/2..3

* Flag off by default, to make it easier to re-land later if it gets

reverted again.

* The test that caused the revert was disabled.



What this this CL does:

* Introduce a new dirty bit called needs_update_ that is meant to

indicate whether step (2) below should happen for that AX object,

or one of its descendants.

* Implement a first piece of step (2): walk the AX tree from the root, updating children and attributes for

all AX objects that have the dirty bit. Early out if the bit is not set.



This CL is written (on purpose) to be a change that should have no

effect on correctness (no effect, because the tree will still lazily

update even if this update doesn't happen, or is incomplete). However,

it may reduce the impact of existing bugs that only reproduce during

lazy updates outside of rendering (such as during serialization or some other code path that reads AX data).





This is one small step towards changing the lifecycle update code to

be like this:



1. Invalidate parts of the AX tree (via methods like ProcessInvalidatedObjects, ProcessCleanLayoutCallbacks, and ProcessUpdatesWithCleanLayout).



2. Update the invalidated parts of the tree.



This end state will avoid problems where tree updates happen

unexpectedly, leading to crashes and other errors.



Subsequent CLs will gradually reduce the amount of eager rebuilding

that happens during (1) and do it in (2) instead, and also gradually

replace code in (1) with dirty-bit setting.



Follow-up tasks:



1. Add CHECKS for cached value accessors once https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4466969 lands.



2. Ensure that the second AX tree update only fixes maps and aria relations.



Perf test results from blink_perf.accessibility:



ProcessDeferredAccessibilityEvents got slower, and RenderAccessibilityImpl::SendPendingAccessibilityEvents got faster. The net difference was very small, about 16ms net across a number of tests. None of the blink_perf.accessibility tests got substantially

slower (and a few got a little bit faster).



Bug: 1342801



This reverts commit 89143d801c7cc5f36e984f8fb6faadcb26861f42.

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4536899

entry.title: Refactor GuestOS protocol handler interface.
entry.content:
First step towards implementing

go/borealis-installer-entry-point#heading=h.gjmxdv9g632b.



* Abstracts "app registrations" from "URL handlers". In this model,

a "URL handler" is just a name and a callback, so can be constructed

without necessarily needing a Registration. This will be needed in

the next step.



* Most logic moves into GuestOsRegistryService as a side-effect.

Since it houses the app list, it also becomes responsible for checking

which apps support which protocols, and creating the handler callback.

This change is not strictly necessary, but it feels more natural,

and gives us a place to register non-app URL handlers in the next CL.

entry.title: Pass state instead of value to formStateRestoreCallback
entry.content:
Per spec [1], the callback should be called with state instead of value

but Blink has been calling it with value. This patch fixes that.



Blink also automatically restores the value before firing the callback,

which isn't standard (as WebKit doesn't do that), but there can be sites

relying on that, so this patch keeps this behavior.

entry.title: webauthn: minor tweaks to request JSON serialization
entry.content:
Some small improvements to the code serializing WebAuthn requests, which is used by the chrome.webAuthenticationProxy extensions API

and for talking to the Android CredMan API:



- Treat PublicKeyCredentialUserEntityJSON.user_display_name as required,

like the spec does.

- Omit `extensions` if it is empty on both

PublicKeyCredentialRequestOptionsJSON and

PublicKeyCredentialRegistrationOptionsJSON, since it is optional.

Previously, we emitted an empty dict, which isn't wrong, but is

superfluous.



Also resolve TODOs in the header to reference the JSON IDL, which

had not yet been spec'd when the code was originally written.

entry.title: [CR2023] Remove toggle button horizontal offset in CR2023.
entry.content:
In the Pageinfo dialog, the toggle button is not right-aligned with the other rows in the view. For example, the toggle button and the launch icon seem mismatched in the page info cookie view. This is caused by a horizontal offset in the Toggle button.



With the updated UI for the toggle button in CR2023, there does not seem to be a need for this horizontal offset anymore. Fix is to just set the offset to 0 so the toggle button is right aligned with the rest of the view.



https://screenshot.googleplex.com/AGEmH2GCQRvYob3



Bug: 1443661, 1422123

entry.title: [User Education] Use acceleration for help bubble widgets on Linux
entry.content:
See attached bug. Help bubbles are cut off/not rendered when anchored to smaller windows on Linux (and probably Lacros) because they are not accelerated by default. Enabling acceleration allows them to float properly and attach to e.g. menus without graphical glitches.



Also improves some tests around help bubbles to make sure we don't cause any regressions with this change. The specific case is not tested for regression due to it being nearly impossible to access the relevant information in the widget.



Follow-up:

- make sure that focusing a help bubble attached to a menu does not

inadvertently close the menu (we already have this facility for

bubble dialogs)

entry.title: Change web expose navigation id to random UUID string
entry.content:
This CL changes the navigation id of the LocalDOMWindow from an int to a

random UUID that is a string. The nav id increments each time there is a

soft nav or bfcache nav. Now the nav id would change to another random

UUID. This is to make the navigation id non-sequential so we can record

it into UKM.



Things to note

1, The WTF::CreateCanonicalUUIDString() is used, instead of the

Crypto::randomUUID(). These 2 are the same. The latter is used only in

v8 code and the former is used in all other places.



2, Previously the navigation is an int with a default number. So if the

nav id is the default number, we know no soft nav or bfcache nav happens.

With nav ids being UUIDs now, the nav id at the LocalDOMWindow creation

time is initiated to a UUID no different than other UUIDs generated after

each soft nav or bfcache nav. Thus by just looking UUIDs, we no longer

know if the current Dom has gone thru soft nav and bfcache nav unless we

keep the initial UUID and compare. It is not a problem. Just note the

difference.



3, The test case, PerformanceTimelineNavigationIdBrowserTest

_NonBackForwardCacheRestore is removed as now the nav id would be

re-generated and different regardless navigation type.

The other test case PerformanceTimelineNavigationIdBrowserTest

_BackForwardCacheRestore is modified accordingly. It now verifies that

each bfcache navigation would change the nav id too.

entry.title: Clean up a pending commit RenderFrameHosts if the renderer crashes.
entry.content:
When a RenderFrameHost's render process crashes, `RenderProcessGone()`

marks the RenderFrameHost as "must be replaced". If the RenderFrameHost

is in the speculative state, `RenderProcessGone()` also destroys `this`,

since a speculative RenderFrameHost with a crashed renderer can

never successfully commit a navigation.



`RenderFrameHostManager::GetFrameHostForNavigation()` asserts that this

cleanup happens by DCHECKing that `speculative_render_frame_host_`, if

any, is not marked as "must be replaced".



However, this cleanup step only applied to speculative RFHs before they

entered the commit commit state; after entering the pending commit

state, the RFH would be marked as "must be replaced" but would not be

destroyed, tripping the DCHECK in `GetFrameHostForNavigation()`.



The fix is also destroy pending commit RFHs when the renderer process

crashes; similarly to speculative RFHs, they can no longer successfully

commit a navigation.



This ends up being a bit tricky due to tripping another DCHECK though:

RenderFrameHostImpl's destructor calls `ResetOwnedNavigationRequests()`,

which DCHECKs that, when navigation queueing is enabled, the reason for

resetting the navigation requests is the render process is gone or the

frame tree node is being removed. This DCHECK is intended to prevent

bugs where the pending commit RFH is unintentionally destroyed instead

of waiting for the pending commit to complete.



But since C++ destructors do not take any arguments, the destructor

always passes kRenderFrameHostDestruction as the reason to discard those

navigations, even though the *caller* knows that the *actual* reason is

kRenderProcessGone, which trips the aforementioned DCHECK when

destroying the pending commit RFH.



To fix this this DCHECK, `UnsetSpeculativeRenderFrameHost()` now

advances the lifecycle state to `kReadyToBeDeleted` to explicitly signal

that it is OK to delete the RFH, despite the fact that was in the

pending commit state.



Bug: 1421404

Change-Id: Ifba7c6d9002c1d923245a282caa8fdeaeca0dbe2

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4529195

Reviewed-by: Alex Moshchuk

Reviewed-by: Rakina Zata Amni

entry.title: Opt-in/out status should be false for WILL_FAIL_REQUEST
entry.content:
Based on crash reports, we seem to be attempting to call

ChildProcessSecurityPolicyImpl::

AddOriginIsolationStateForBrowsingInstance() from

NavigationRequest::AddOriginAgentClusterStateIfNecessary() when the

NavigationRequest's `state_` is WILL_FAIL_REQUEST. This seems to be

happening on non-HTTP/HTTPS urls, which is puzzling since they should

not have any headers, and Origin-Agent-Cluster would need to be present.

In any case WILL_FAIL_REQUEST by itself seems like a valid reason to

prevent any opt-in or opt-out requests.



Landing this as a speculative fix while we further investigate the

unusual schemes in the urls.



Low-Coverage-Reason: speculative fix for crash, tests to follow.

entry.title: Fix error in PageAction metrics logging
entry.content:
Previously, page action metrics were being reported incorrectly, as

switching to a new background tab never triggered logging for any page

actions already shown on that tab, and tracking for whether logging had

occurred was global rather than per-URL. This CL addresses both of these

issues.



OBSOLETE_HISTOGRAM[PageActionController.PagesWithActionsShown]=

Replaced with PageActionController.PagesWithActionsShown2
